Answer: There are currently no Commonwealth Supported Places available to postgraduate students.

Question: Are placements available part time for education students?
Answer: When attending placement you are required to attend full days (seven to eight hours per day). We recommend you complete your placement five days per week over four weeks. You also have the option of completing some placements three consecutive days per week (e.g. Wed, Thurs, Fri) over eight weeks.

Question: Are exams only held at the end of each teaching period?
Answer: Yes, you are only required to attend exams at the end of each teaching period. There are no formal mid-semester exams.

Question: Am I eligible for a student concession card when studying online?
Answer: Yes, you can request a student card when you enrol with Swinburne Online. You can use this to borrow books at Swinburne University of Technology’s library or any ULANZ libraries and will also need it when you attend exams.

Question: Am I eligible for a Commonwealth Supported Place and a HELP loan?
Answer:
ACommonwealth Supported Place(CSP) is a subsidised higher education place. You will only pay the student contribution (remaining amount) of the unit fees after the government subsidy has been applied.

AHECS-HELP loanwill allow you to defer your fees to a government loan forCSP courses, allowing you to avoid any upfront fees for your course. You would start to pay this loan back once you are earning over the advised threshold. This loan is available to Australian citizens and Humanitarian Visa holders.

AFEE-HELP loanwill allow you to defer your fees to a government loan for full fee paying places (non-CSP) allowing you to avoid any upfront fees for your course. You would start to pay this loan back once you are earning over the advised threshold. This loan is available to Australian citizens and Humanitarian Visa holders. You can nominate to defer your fees to a HELP loan during your enrolment, and once you log into your student account that application can be finalised.

Question: Am I able to study at Swinburne Online if I don't live in Victoria?
Answer: You can study at Swinburne Online from any state or territory in Australia, as long as you meet the entry requirements for youronline courseand have an Internet connection! Swinburne Online now accepts international students into our university degrees. You can find out more about ourentry criteria for international students here.

Question: What kind of support can I expect?
Answer: As a Swinburne Online student, you’ll have support for extended hours, seven days a week, with Student Advisors available to help with anything from tech support to research advice and dedicated online tutors in each of your units. Learn more aboutyour support.

Question: What kind of support can I expect?

Question: Are stars paid?
Answer: All students enrolled in the STARS program will receive a $900 stipend to help with the cost of their studies or professional placement.

Question: Does STARS pay its employees?

Answer: All students enrolled in the STARS program will be given a $900 Stipend to help with the cost of their education or professional placement.

Question: Are STARS placements extra placements or part of my course?
Answer: The StarS Professional Placements are part of the required professional placements in your course. They are not additional placements.

Question: Do STARS placements count as additional placements or as a component of my course?
Answer: The STARS professional placements are a component of the mandatory professional placements in your course. They are not additional placements.

Question: Is STARS placements extra placements or part of my curriculum?
Answer: The STARS professional placements are part of your course's mandatory professional placements; they are not extra placements.

Question: Can I complete my two STARS placements in the school that I am doing Permission To Teach (PTT) work? The school fits the low-socioeconomic criteria and have said they would be happy for me to do my STARS placement there?

Question: Is it possible for me to complete my two STARS placements in the school that I am currently studying Permission To Teach (PTT)?
Answer: You will be able to complete your final two placements through the STARS program at your school. You can also continue with PTT throughout the year. For example, you may have three days in STARS and two days in PTT. The STARS part of the program requires supervision and you can also take the GTPA (final placement assessment). If you have any questions, please contact Jade at edpartnerships@swinburneonline.com.

Question: Can I complete my two STARS placements in the school where I am doing Permission To Teach (PTT) work? The school has stated that they would be able to accommodate me for my STARS placements there.

Question: Will Swinburne match me to somewhere within a reasonable distance from my home or could it be anywhere in regional/rural Victoria?
Answer: Swinburne will try to match you to a school as close as possible to your usual place of residence. The maximum travel time from your home to the school will be 90 minutes, however, every endeavour will be made to ensure it is less than this.

Question: Will I be charged interest on my HECS loan?

Question: Is there an interest fee for a HECS-HELP loan?

Question: Will I be charged interest on my HELP loan?

Question: What is TAFE?
Answer: TAFE (TAFE) is the term used by the Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA), which is the national regulator for Australia's Vocational Education and Training sector. ASQA regulates courses and training providers to ensure nationally approved quality standards are met.

Question: What exactly is meant by the term TAFE?
Answer: Technical and Further Education (TAFE) is the term used to describe certain state-administered education institutions that offer Vocational Education and Training (VET) and qualifying courses under the National Training System, Australian Qualifications Framework and Australian Quality Training Network. A Registered Training Organisation (RTO) is an organisation accredited by the Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA) which is the national regulator for Australia's vocational education and training sector. ASQA regulates courses and training providers to ensure that they meet national approved quality standards.

Question: What is TAFE? What is TAFE?
Answer: A Registered Training Organisation (RTO) is an entity that is registered by the Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA), Australia's national regulator for vocational education and training, and the Australian Quality Training Network (TAFE) is the national regulator for Australia's vocational education and training sector.

Question: What is distance education?
Answer: Distance education (sometimes known as learning by correspondence) is a broad term that describes education delivered back and forth between the student and learning institution in hard copy. This method of education has been around since the 1800s and is often considered outdated in comparison with online education offered by Swinburne Online. Many distance education programs require the student to attend classes or workshops on campus at some stage during the semester.

Question: Can you explain the concept of Distance Education?

It involves delivering course content to a student who is not physically present at the learning institution, unlike online education provided by Swinburne Online. The method typically involves sending the course materials and assessments back and forth in hard copy, and many distance education programs necessitated the student to attend classes or workshops on campus at some point during the semester.

Question: What is PhD?
Answer: To be awarded with a PhD, you must select a specific subject within your chosen field, carry out extensive and original research, and submit a substantial thesis. Your thesis will be evaluated by external examiners and judged on the quality of your original research and contribution to the knowledge of the subject. You'll be required to study full-time for three or four years and be supervised by academic staff. After graduating, you will have the opportunity to teach in your chosen field at a university level or work in a specialised

Question: What is Commonwealth Supported Place?
Answer: The Australian Government subsidises an Australian citizen student's education by giving them a Commonwealth supported place, by which they pay part of the course fees directly to the university and the student pays the remainder.

Question: What does the term Commonwealth Supported Place mean?
Answer: Australian citizen students are eligible for a Commonwealth supported place for their education, but only if they are a domestic undergraduate student and the government pays a portion of their course fees directly to the university.

Question: What is a Commonwealth Supported Place?
Answer: If you are a domestic undergraduate student, you are eligible for a Commonwealth supported place. The Australian Government subsidises an Australian citizen student's education by giving them a Commonwealth supported place.

Question: What is certificate?
Answer: Certificates are the most basic qualification available to secondary school students and beyond. Offered by TAFEs, Community Education Centres and Registered Training Providers, certificates I, II, III and IV will prepare you for employment or further learning.

Question: Can you explain what a Certificate is?
Answer: Certificates I, II, III and IV are the most basic qualifications available to secondary school students and beyond. Offered by TAFEs, Community Education Centres and Registered Training Providers, they will prepare you for employment or further education. Certificate I:Will give you skills when starting a profession or help you gain community involvement. Certificate III:You will learn more in-depth theoretical and practical skills for work or further learning. Certificate IV:You will learn theoretical and practical skills for specialised work or further learning.

Question: What is a Certificate?
Answer: Certificates I, II, III, III, and IV, which are the most basic qualification available to secondary school students and beyond, will prepare you for work or further education, as well as continuing education and training.Certificate III:You'll learn more in-depth theoretical and practical skills for work or further education.

Question: What is a bachelor degree?
Answer: Bachelor degrees are offered by universities and are presented to you when you complete an undergraduate course of study. Where a diploma will give you the skills you need for your job, a bachelor degree will set you up for your career. Depending on the field of study, the duration of the degree can range from three to five years of full-time study (or part-time equivalent). Most bachelor degrees are recognised worldwide.

Question: Could you provide a description of what a Bachelor Degree entails?
Answer: Universities offer Bachelor degrees to individuals who complete an undergraduate course. The duration of the degree can range from three to five years of full-time study (or part-time equivalent) depending on the area of study. A Bachelor degree is recognised as a higher qualification than a diploma or certificate. Where a Diploma will provide you with the skills you need for your job, a Bachelor will set you up for your career.

Question: What is a Bachelor Degree?
Answer: Bachelor degrees are available at universities and are recognized as a higher qualification or part-time equivalent, and where a Bachelor degree prepares you for your career, it can vary from three to five years of full-time study (or part-time equivalent).

Question: If I have just completed year 12, can I apply to join your March intake (Teaching period 1)?
Answer: No, recent year 12 students must apply through VTAC for Swinburne courses for the March intake, but you may apply for the July or November intakes.

Question: If I have just finished Year 12 (Teaching Period 1), can I still apply to be enrolled in your intake for March (Teaching Period 1), given that I have recently completed Year 12?
Answer: VTAC is the only option for recent Year 12 students to apply for Swinburne courses for the March intake. However, applicants for Swinburne Online’s July or November intakes may apply directly.

Question: If I have just completed Year 12, can I enroll in your March intake (Teaching Period 1)?
Answer: However, you can apply for Swinburne Online's July or November intakes. No, new Year 12 students must register through VTAC for Swinburne courses for the March intake.

Question: If I have a VSL can I withdraw from my course?
Answer: Withdrawing before Census: To avoid incurring a VET FEE HELP or VET Student Loan debt (or to receive a full refund if you pay for your fees upfront) you must send your email to Swinburne Online on or before your census date. We will inform you of your Census dates when you enrolled.

Question: If I have a VSL, can I withdraw from my course?
Answer: To withdraw from your course if you paid your fees upfront or applied for VET FEE HELP or VET Student Loan, please complete the self-service withdrawal request form and send it to Swinburne Online within 10 business days. If you withdraw after Census, you will be charged for the units you enrolled in.

Question: Can I withdraw from my program if I have a VSL?
Answer: Withdrawal After Census: If you paid your fees upfront or applied for a VET FEE HELP or a VET Student Loan before Census, you will be charged for the units you enrolled in. You will not be able to recover your refund within ten business days.

Question: I'm studying a degree, will I have to sit exams?
Answer: Exam attendance is necessary for all of our courses, other than education courses, our Bachelor of Design (Communication Design) and some media studies units. When students reside more than 100km from an exam centre or have any condition that would prevent them from taking exams at exam centres, they can sit an online exam. Exams are taken at specified exam centre venues in capital cities around Australia. To find out more about exams, visit ourassessments and examspage on the website.

Question: Do I need to sit for any exams as a student of a degree program?
Answer: All of our courses, except for education courses, our Bachelor of Design (Communication Studies) and some media studies units, require students to attend exams at specified exam centres in capital cities around Australia. If students are unable to take exams at exam centres due to physical disability, they can take an online exam. All our international students will also be required to sit their exams online, at home using a personal computer. For more information, visit ourassessments and examspage on the website.

Question: If I'm taking a degree, will I have to sit exams?
Answer: Students in all of our programs, other than education, our Bachelor of Design (Communication Design), and some media studies units are also required to sit their exams online, at home using a personal computer.

Question: I am interested in becoming a teacher. How will teaching placements work, given that your degrees are online?
Answer: Students studying our online education courses still have to complete placements like on-campus students. In order to register to teach, graduates must have completed at least 60 days of professional placement when studying at postgraduate level and at least 80 days at undergraduate level. Professional placements can be taken anywhere in Australia, in schools using the Australian curriculum or early childhood settings that use the Early Years Learning Framework.

Question: I’m interested in pursuing a career as a teacher. Can you tell me if there will be any online teaching opportunities for graduates with online degrees?
Answer: Our online education courses do not require students to complete on-campus placements like on-campus students. To register as teachers, graduates must have completed at least 60 days of professional placement when studying at postgraduate level and at least 80 days at undergraduate level. Professional placements can be taken in any location in Australia, in schools that follow the Australian curriculum or early childhood settings that use the Early Years Learning Framework.

Question: I'm interested in becoming a teacher, so teaching placements will function? Given that your degrees are online, how will teaching placements function?
Answer: Graduates studying at least 60 days of professional placement when studying at undergraduate level and at least 80 days at undergraduate level must have completed placements that use the Early Years Learning Framework in order to register to teach.

Question: How many units can I teach per teaching period?

Question: How many hours should I study per week?
Answer: For most undergraduate students, we recommend you allow eight hours of study per week. For postgraduate education students (domestic only), we recommend 10 hours a week per unit and for postgraduate business students and undergraduate design students we recommend 12 hours per week of study.

Question: How many hours per week should I study per unit of study?

Question: How many hours of study per week are recommended per unit?
Answer: For most undergraduate students (domestic only), we recommend ten hours of study per week, and for undergraduate business students and undergraduate design students, we recommend allowing 12 hours per week per unit.

Question: How does your online study work for higher education?
Answer: We know students are most successful when they learn actively. This means not just remembering new information, but testing it and using it to solve problems and sharing with other classmates in the discussion boards.

Question: How does your model of online study for higher education function without the need for lectures?
Answer: Swinburne Online emphasizes the importance of active learning, which involves not only memorizing new information but also evaluating and utilizing it to solve problems and generate new ideas. Students learn theory through the use of free Learning Materials, practice with weekly Learning Activities, and share their learning with classmates in the Discussion Boards.

Question: How can your model of online study for higher education work if there are no lectures?
Answer: Students at Swinburne Online learn with the three learning elements: theory, practice, and sharing. Students learn how to solve problems and come up with new ideas by actively engaging with it, not just remembering new information, but also sharing your findings with other classmates in the Discussion Boards.

Question: How can I repay my HELP loan?
Answer: HECS, FEE, and VET FEE-HELP enable eligible students to state their intention for tuition fees to be paid on their behalf by the Federal Government to Swinburne Online. Repayments for HELP loans are not required until students earn more than a certain amount per annum. This results in students having a loan with the Australian Tax Office that can be repaid through the tax system.

Question: What is the process for repaying my HELP loan?
Answer: Students who qualify for the program, known as HECS-HELP, FEE-HELP or VET FEE-HELP, can inform Swinburne Online in advance about their plan to be paid on their behalf by the federal government. This will enable them to obtain a loan from the Australian Tax Office that can be repaid through the tax system. HELP loans are not refundable until students are earning a certain amount of income per year.

Question: How can I repay my HELP loan?
Answer: HECS-HELP, FEE-HELP, and VET FEE-HELP are all eligible students who are eligible for tuition fees to be paid by the federal government to Swinburne Online, which has resulted in students being able to obtain a loan with the Australian Tax Office that can be repaid through the tax system until students are earning more than a certain amount per annum.

Question: Are education degrees nationally recognised?

The Bachelor of Education (Primary), Bachelor of Education (Early Childhood and Primary), Master of Teaching (Primary) and Master of Teaching (Secondary) allow you to register as a teacher in any Australian state or territory under mutual recognition.

Question: Are there any part time placements for education students?

You will only pay the student contribution (remaining amount) of the unit fees, allowing you to avoid any upfront fees for your course.

You can choose to pay only the student contribution (remaining amount) of the unit fees after the government subsidy has been applied.
